key_points: Hurricane Ida, a Category 4 storm, made landfall in Port Fourchon, Louisiana, with 150 mile-per-hour winds.
Louisiana Governor John Bel Edwards warns of the severe challenges the state faces in the coming days and weeks due to Hurricane Ida.
The hurricane arrived on the anniversary of Hurricane Katrina and two days after the anniversary of Hurricane Laura.
Residents in southeastern Louisiana are advised to shelter in place for 72 hours after the storm passes.
Louisiana's entire National Guard and additional personnel from 16 other states are gearing up for search and rescue missions.
Hurricane Ida hit coastal towns hard, with more populous areas, including New Orleans and Baton Rouge, expected to face significant impacts.
Despite mandatory evacuations in many coastal parishes, New Orleans did not issue one due to the storm's rapid approach.
The state has improved its hurricane preparedness, leveraging a new protection system built around New Orleans since Hurricane Katrina.
Hospitals, already at capacity due to COVID-19, face challenges in evacuation and power outages, but are preparing for impact.
Louisiana is providing public shelters and transportation to safer areas, and is working to mitigate COVID-19 spread among evacuees.
